column1: #Text=The  Mg  and  B  powders  used  in  the  present  study  were  purchased  from  Furuchi  Chemical  Corporation,  Japan.
#Text=Polycrystalline MgB2 samples were made using the in-situ solid state reaction.
#Text=High-purity commercial powders of Mg  (99.9%  purity,  200  meshes)  and  amorphous  B  powder  (99%  purity,  300  meshes)  were  mixed  in  a  nominal  composition  of  MgB2.
#Text=The  starting  powders  were  thoroughly  ground  in  a  glove  box  under  argon  atmosphere.
#Text=The  powder mixture was pressed into pellets of 20 mm in diameter using a hydraulic press.
#Text=Eventually, a Ti sheet was wrapped  around  the  tightly  pressed  pellets  that  were  then  sintered  in  argon  atmosphere  in  a  tubular  furnace.

#Text=The  samples  were  prepared  in  a  single  step  heat  process  with  the  following  heat  treatment  profile:  The  sintering  temperature was chosen to be 775 oC as in the previous experiments [8].
#Text=The temperature was raised in 5 h from the ambient temperature.
#Text=During the sintering in flowing argon gas the temperature was kept constant for 3 hours.
#Text=Then, the  temperature  was  reduced  to  room  temperature  with  the  cooling  rate  of  100  oC/h.
#Text=After  sintering,  the  Ti  sheets  were removed from the MgB2 bulks.
#Text=Then, the samples were re-sintered in a single step at 660 oC for 24, 45, 72 and 100 hours, respectively.
#Text=The samples are of good quality with no cracks (see Fig.1).
